New Records: Shohei Ohtani hit his 47th home run of the season, tying a franchise record for most home runs in a single season by a Japanese-born player.
Tommy Edman hit his 4th home run of the season, extending his streak of consecutive games with a home run to 4.
Michael Kopech recorded his 13th save of the season, tying a franchise record for most saves in a single season by a pitcher who began their career in the 21st century.
Key Match Events: Shohei Ohtani hit a solo home run in the bottom of the 1st inning, driving in the first run of the game.
Cody Bellinger hit a grand slam in the top of the 5th inning, scoring 4 runs and giving the Dodgers a 6-2 lead.
Seiya Suzuki was caught stealing 3rd base in the top of the 9th inning, which prevented the Cubs from scoring the potential tying run.
Trey Wingenter pitched a perfect 8th inning, retiring all three batters he faced to keep the Dodgers' lead intact.
Pre-Game Insights: The Cubs entered the game with a 75-71 record, looking to build momentum after a strong performance in their previous game.
The Dodgers were aiming to extend their winning streak to 5 games after a dominant performance in their previous matchup.
Post-Match Reflections: Alex Vesia, the winning pitcher for the Cubs, expressed relief after securing the victory in the bottom of the 9th inning.
Manager David Ross of the Cubs praised the team's resilience after overcoming a late deficit to win the game.
Miscellaneous Highlights: The game was played under clear skies with a temperature of 70 degrees at first pitch.
The attendance at Dodger Stadium was 48,691 fans, a strong showing for a mid-week game.
